awd_titl_txt: Type I: UC Riverside - EPIC I-Corps Site for Entrepreneurship in Riverside County
awd_abstract_narration:
This project, from the University of California - Riverside (UCR), creates an I-Corps Site at this institution. 

NSF Innovation Corps (I-Corps) Sites are NSF-funded entities established at universities whose purpose is to nurture and support multiple, local teams to transition their technology concepts into the marketplace. Sites provide infrastructure, advice, resources, networking opportunities, training and modest funding to enable groups to transition their work into the marketplace or into becoming I-Corps Team applicants. I-Corps Sites also strengthen innovation locally and regionally and contribute to the National Innovation Network of mentors, researchers, entrepreneurs and investors.

This I-Corps Site is managed by the UC Riverside Entrepreneurial Proof of Concept and Innovation Center (EPIC). EPIC is a regional program that operates in partnership with the County and major local cities to offer a suite of services and tools to help teams of innovators and entrepreneurs launch knowledge-based companies. In addition, UCR partnered with Riverside City College to allow their upper level students to participate as I-Corps team members. To ensure representative participation of females and students from underrepresented minorities, EPIC designates successful I-Corps graduates as Student Ambassadors to promote and mentor students from those two groups. Teams completing the EPIC I-Corps workshops receive additional support from EPIC's suite of services and from other programs offered by EPIC's network of regional partners.

Active collaboration with the region's universities and community colleges, regional incubators and accelerators create synergies within the region and accelerate development of the needed ecosystem that will attract and create knowledge-based companies and jobs. The success of EPIC and the UCR NSF I-Corps site are instrumental in the creation of the ecosystem needed to support innovation and entrepreneurship at UCR and in Riverside County, a region that lacks history and experience in entrepreneurism. Long-term outcomes of this initiative will be greater retention of UCR graduates in the region, increased employment from company creation and the relocation of knowledge-based businesses to Riverside County. These high-paying technology jobs represent a major economic stimulus into a region whose economy has historically been based on agriculture and low-wage jobs.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF CALIFORNIA AT RIVERSIDE

por.por_cntn:
The NSF I-Corps site has been transformational for UC Riverside in creating an entrepreneurial culture on campus. This award has led to the creation of more than ten different initiatives to support campus and community innovators and entrepreneurs explore the commercialization of their ideas. To date, the university has built a complete infrastructure to support I&E initiatives that has resulted in the support of over 600 innovators who have raised a total of $74 Million in private capital and grants.

At the completion of the Site Award, the Office of Technology Partnerships (OTP) and UCR are in a much stronger position with regards to I&E education and practice.

The first year of the Site's activities signaled to the campus that OTP had validation from the NSF for our path-to-market for university startups. The fact that the Site Program was managed centrally through UC Riverside's Office of the Vice Chancellor for Research ensure that the program was available to all units across campus - including arts & humanities and natural sciences, and not just business and STEM. Participation of faculty, graduate students and undergraduates from music, public policy, English and agriculture has been an important achievement of this outreach, in addition to serving our core audiences in engineering, computer science, business, and medicine.

The following are some of the key metrics that the UCR NSF I-Corps site accomplished during the five years of operation:

  • Number of NSF I-Corps Workshops delivered by UCR: 13
  • Duration of each Workshop: 7 Weeks
  • Number of teams participating in the program: 166
  • Total number of UCR students that participated in the program: 450
  • Total number of UCR faculty:  80
  • Number of teams that participated in the National program: 7
  • Number of mentors/instructors recruited: 27
  • Approximate number of mentoring hours: 5,810 mentor hours
  • Approximate number of interviews: 2500
  • Number of companies launched: 22
  • Number of invention disclosures submitted by faculty: 53 

Additional insights were gained from a survey sent by OTP to representatives from all 166 teams that participated to gain insights into their experience of the program and how it could be improved in the future. The following is the summary of the 37 responses: 

  • Ethnic composition of respondents: 32% Asian; 27% White; 22% Hispanic; 3% Black
  • Poor response from female participants
  • 35% of the respondents started or were in-process of starting a business
  • 9 patents or disclosures reported  
  • 8 teams joined incubators
  • Follow on funding of $4.86 million reported including: $1.1M in grants, $3.5M in private investment, $270k in Proof-of-Concept Grants from UCR and $25k in Awards.

Additional insights gained include:

  • The importance of industry mentors who are trained in I-Corps principles. I-Corps customer discovery is not intuitive or obvious for most deep tech lab researchers. Providing a qualified mentor to meet regularly with the team proved invaluable in team understanding and accomplishments.
  • The importance of diversity, equity, and inclusion as a foundational element of I-Corps, and the impact that program delivery, language and mentor diversity have in team participation and engagement.
  • Funds for participant support were key not only as a recruiting tool but to enable the teams to attend professional and industry conferences and meetings to conduct customer discovery.
  • The Impact of the I-Corps program on the participant's journey needs to be measured well beyond the duration of the actual workshop. OTP found that additional support in the form of personalized mentorship and access to proof-of-concept funds resulted in projects raising a total of $8.2 Million through a combination of sponsored research, SBIR grants and investment capital.

The UCR NSF I-Corps Site Program has also been the starting point for many new programs launched by the Office of Technology Partnerships over the past 5 years:

  • Highlander Venture Fund- $5 Million pre-seed investment fund targeting Inland Empire Startups 
  • Blackstone Launchpad - Entrepreneurial Education and mentoring to over 3,000 undergraduate students 
  • Riverside ExCITE - technology incubator managed by UCR and launched in partnership with the City and the County of Riverside. ExCITE serves as a graduation space for I-Corps participants. 
  • EPIC-Small Business Development Center - Funded by the SBA and the State of California, program offers mentorship and access to capital to technology startups from UCR and the community.
  • Life Science Incubator - A campus resource for I-Corps life science projects which seek a proving ground with equipped lab space. 
  • SBIR/STTR Resource Center - advice and proposal submission support for I-Corps participants.
  • INNOVAR - Customer discovery workshop developed for Latin American Partners

Last Modified: 10/31/2022
Modified by: Rosibel Ochoa
